Unit 3: [[EPR (nuclear reactor)|EPR]] | ps_units_uc = 1 × 1600 MW [[EPR (nuclear reactor)|EPR]] | ps_units_planned = | ps_units_cancelled = | ps_units_decommissioned= | ps_thermal_capacity = 2 × 3817 MWth | ps_heating_capacity = | ps_electrical_capacity = 2660 | ps_electrical_cap_fac = 60.08% (2017)
70.55% (lifetime) | ps_storage_hours = | ps_annual_generation = 13,999 GWh (2017) | website = [https://www.edf.fr/groupe-edf/producteur-industriel/carte-des-implantations/centrale-nucleaire-de-flamanville/presentation Centrale nucléaire de Flamanville]
[https://www.edf.fr/en/groupe-edf/producteur-industriel/carte-des-implantations/centrale-nucleaire-de-flamanville-3/presentation Centrale nucléaire de Flamanville 3] | extra = }} The '''Flamanville Nuclear Power Plant''' is located at [[Flamanville, Manche]], [[France]] on the [[Cotentin Peninsula]]. The [[power plant]] houses two [[pressurized water reactor]]s (PWRs) that produce 1.3 [[GWe|GWe]] each and came into service in 1986 and 1987, respectively. It produced 18.9 TWh in 2005, which amounted to 4% of the electricity production in France. In 2006 this figure was about 3.3%. A third reactor at the site, a [[EPR (nuclear reactor)|EPR]] unit, is currently under construction. As of July 2016, the project was three times over budget and years behind schedule. Various safety problems have been raised, including weakness in the steel used in the reactor.Jennifer Rankin. [https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/jul/27/flamanville-france-edf-nuclear-reactor-hinkley-point-c Flamanville: France's beleaguered forerunner to Hinkley Point C], ''The Guardian'', 27 July 2016. [[Image:Flamanville 1978, des explosifs détruisent la falaise et l'ancienne mine de fer sous-marine pour la centrale nucléaire.jpg|thumbnail|left|1978 picture showing the blasting that was done to demolish the cliffs and old, under-sea iron ore mines, before the reactors were built.]] In 2006, before the start of construction of the EPR (unit 3), there were 671 workers regularly working at the two operational reactors. ==Unit 3== {{See also|EPR (nuclear reactor)#Flamanville 3 (France)}} Construction on a new reactor, Flamanville 3, began on 4 December 2007. {{Cite news | url = http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/newsarticle.aspx?id=14496 | work=World Nuclear News | date=2007-12-04 | title= Construction of Flamanville EPR begins | accessdate= 2011-03-19}} The new unit is an [[Areva]] [[European Pressurized Reactor]] type and is planned to have a [[nameplate capacity]] of 1,650 MWe. EDF has previously said France's first EPR would cost €3.3 billion and start commercial operations in 2012, after construction lasting 54 months.{{Cite news|url=http://www.neimagazine.com/story.asp?sectionCode=132&storyCode=2048041 |title=Flamanville 3 concrete poured |newspaper=Nuclear Engineering International |date=6 December 2007 |accessdate=1 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613091002/http://www.neimagazine.com/story.asp?sectionCode=132&storyCode=2048041 |archivedate=June 13, 2011 }} The latest cost estimate (July 2018) is at €10.9 billion. On 3 December 2012 EDF announced that the estimated costs have escalated to €8.5 billion ($11 billion), and the completion of construction is delayed to 2016.{{Cite news | url = http://www.lemonde.fr/planete/article/2012/12/03/le-cout-de-l-epr-de-flamanville-encore-revu-a-la-hausse_1799417_3244.html | agency=Le Monde | date=3 December 2012 | title=Le coût de l'EPR de Flamanville encore revu à la hausse| accessdate=4 December 2012}} The next day the Italian power company [[Enel]] announced it was relinquishing its 12.5% stake in the project, and 5 future EPRs, so would be reimbursed its project stake of €613 million plus interest.{{cite news |url=http://www.powermag.com/enel-drops-participation-in-flamanville-epr-as-project-costs-soar-by-2-6b/ |title=Enel Drops Participation in Flamanville EPR as Project Costs Soar by $2.6B |newspaper=POWER |date=6 December 2012 |accessdate=14 August 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.enel.com/en-GB/media/press_releases/enel-and-edf-terminate-their-cooperation-on-epr-in-france/r/1656525 |title=Enel and Edf Terminate their cooperation on EPR in France |publisher=Enel |date=4 December 2012 |accessdate=14 August 2013}} In November 2014 EDF announced that completion of construction was delayed to 2017 due to delays in component delivery by [[Areva]].{{cite news |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/adc90b3e-6f67-11e4-8d86-00144feabdc0.html |title=EDF in fresh delay for flagship nuclear plant |author=Michael Stothard |newspaper=Financial Times |date=18 November 2014 |accessdate=21 November 2014}} In April 2015 Areva informed the French nuclear regulator, [[Autorité de sûreté nucléaire]] (ASN), that anomalies had been detected in the reactor vessel steel, causing "lower than expected mechanical toughness values". Further tests are underway.{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS-Flamanville-EPR-vessel-anomalies-under-scrutiny-0704154.html |title=Flamanville EPR vessel anomalies under scrutiny |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=7 April 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2015}}www.asn.fr: [http://www.asn.fr/Informer/Actualites/EPR-de-Flamanville-anomalies-de-fabrication-de-la-cuve Anomalies de fabrication de la cuve de l’EPR de Flamanville]. Communiqué de presse, 7 april 2015 [[Segolene Royal]], [[Ministry of Ecology, Sustainable Development and Energy|Minister of Ecology, Sustainable Development and Energy]] in the [[Second Valls Government]], has asked the producer for further details and possible consequences.8. April 2015: [http://www.greenetvert.fr/2015/04/08/nucleaire-une-nouvelle-anomalie-detectee-sur-lepr-de-flamanville/82548 Nucléaire: une nouvelle anomalie détectée sur l’EPR de Flamanville] Various safety problems have been raised, including weakness in the steel used in the reactorJennifer Rankin. Flamanville: France's beleaguered forerunner to Hinkley Point C, ''The Guardian'', 27 July 2016. together with heterogeneity of the steel alloy forged high integrity components used in the reactor pressure vessel,{{cite web|url=http://www.largeassociates.com/CZ3233/Note_LargeAndAssociates_EN_26092016.pdf|title=Review: Irregularities and Anomalies Relating to the Forged Components of le Creusot Forge, 26 September 2016|accessdate=15 January 2017}} that have also been shown to be present in Japanese-sourced components that have entered the French nuclear equipment supply chain.{{cite web|url=http://www.largeassociates.com/CZ3235/R3235-A1FINAL2410-16.pdf|title=Review: Irregularities and Anomalies Relating to the Nuclear Reactor Primary Coolant Circuit Components Installed in Japanese Nuclear Power Plants - Part 1 French Carbon Anomaly Correlation to Japanese Nuclear Power Plants=24 October 2016|accessdate=15 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.largeassociates.com/CZ3235/R3235-A2-12-12-16-FINAL.pdf|title=Review: Irregularities and Anomalies Relating to the Nuclear Reactor Primary Coolant Circuit Components Installed in Japanese Nuclear Power Plants - Concluding Parts 2 & 3 - Potential Flawed Components Resident in Japanese Nuclear Power Plants=10 December 2016|accessdate=15 January 2017}} The safety of the Flamanville EPR plant has also been questioned due to the danger of flooding of the kind experienced during the [[1999 Blayais Nuclear Power Plant flood]].[http://deciphering-fukushima.blogs.sciencesetavenir.fr/tag/monique%20sen%C3%A9 The great lesson France has to learn from Fukushima] Deciphering Fukushima, published 2011-03-08, accessed 2012-05-08 In June 2015 multiple faults in cooling system safety valves were discovered by ASN.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/11662889/Faulty-valves-in-new-generation-EPR-nuclear-reactor-pose-meltdown-risk-inspectors-warn.html |title=Faulty valves in new-generation EPR nuclear reactor pose meltdown risk, inspectors warn |author=Henry Samuel |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |date=9 June 2015 |accessdate=9 July 2015}} The EPR (Flamanville 3) aimed to be safer than any previous reactor, but as of 2016 the project is three times over budget and years behind schedule. In September 2015 EDF announced that the estimated costs had escalated to €10.5 billion, and the start-up of the reactor was delayed to the fourth quarter of 2018.https://www.edf.fr/en/edf/press_release/Flamanville-EPR-optimised-project-management-and-a-new-timetable The delays of Unit 3 of Flamanville received additional attention when in December 2016 [[The Economist]] reported that the British loan guarantees for [[Hinkley Point C nuclear power station|Hinkley Point C]] require Unit 3 to be operational by 2020, that the regulator will rule on the future of Unit 3 mid-2017 and that one possible outcome of this ruling can delay its opening far beyond 2018, thus jeopardizing the British loan guarantees thereby preventing EDF from building the EPRs at Hinkley Point.{{cite news|url= https://www.economist.com/news/business/21711087-electricit-de-france-has-had-shut-down-18-its-58-nuclear-reactors-frances-nuclear-energy |title= France’s nuclear-energy champion is in turmoil |work= [[The Economist]] |date= 2016-12-03 |accessdate= 2016-12-04}} In February 2017 renewed delays in the construction of the EPR-reactors at [[Taishan Nuclear Power Plant]] prompted EDF to state that Flamanville 3 remains on schedule to start operations by the end of 2018, assuming it receives regulator approval.{{cite news|url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/edf-confirms-flamanville-timetable-after-taishan-epr-delay/articleshow/57294950.cms |title= EDF confirms Flamanville timetable after Taishan EPR delay |work= [[Times of India]] |date= 2017-02-22 |accessdate= 2017-03-09}} In June 2017 the French regulator issued a provisional ruling that Flamanville 3 is safe to start.{{cite news|url= http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS-French-regulator-says-Flamanville-3-is-safe-to-start-29061701.html |website= [[world-nuclear-news.org]] |title= French regulator says Flamanville 3 is safe to start |date= 2017-06-28 |accessdate= 2017-07-03}} In January 2018, cold functional tests were completed.http://world-nuclear-news.org/NN-Flamanville-EPR-completes-key-pre-operational-tests-0901184.html In February EDF found that some secondary cooling circuit welds did not meet specifications, causing EDF to carry out further checks and a report. Following this ASN requested EDF to extend the welding checks to other systems. Hot functional tests have been postponed.{{cite news |url=http://www.neimagazine.com/news/newspossible-reprieve-for-fessenheim-due-to-further-flamanville-delays-6175762 |title=Possible reprieve for Fessenheim due to further Flamanville delays |publisher=Nuclear Engineering International |date=4 June 2018 |accessdate=8 June 2018}} In July 2018, EDF further delayed fuel loading to Q4 2019 and increased the project's cost estimate by a further €400 million ($467.1 million USD). Startup is now scheduled to occur no earlier than Q2 2020 and EDF now estimates project costs at €10.9 billion ($12.75 billion USD), three times the original cost estimates. Hot testing is currently planned to occur by the end of 2018.{{cite news|title=EDF Announces More Delays, Cost Overruns for Flamanville 3 Reactor|url=http://www.powermag.com/edf-announces-more-delays-cost-overruns-for-flamanville-3-reactor/|accessdate=31 July 2018|work=POWER Magazine|date=25 July 2018}} == Incidents == On 9 February 2017 a mechanical problem with a fan in the turbine hall caused an explosion and fire, causing five people to be treated for [[smoke inhalation]]. While the non-nuclear accident did not cause any radioactive leak, it did cause the number one reactor to be disconnected from the power grid.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/french-nuclear-power-plant-explosion-latest-injured-flamanville-la-manche-normandy-accident-fire-a7570876.html|title=French nuclear power plant explosion: 'Several injured' after blast in Flamanville |website= [[independent.co.uk]] |first= Lizzie |last= Dearden |date= 9 February 2017|accessdate=9 February 2017}}{{cite news|url= http://www.ouest-france.fr/normandie/flamanville-50340/explosion-la-centrale-nucleaire-de-flamanville-des-blesses-4790646 |title= Incendie à la centrale nucléaire de Flamanville : ce que l’on sait |website= [[Ouest-France|ouest-france.fr]] |date= 9 February 2017|accessdate=9 February 2017 |language= fr |trans-title=Fire at the Flamanville Nuclear Power Plant: What We Know}} EDF initially estimated the reactor would be operational within a week, but later estimated the end of March.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/feb/21/edf-faces-1m-a-day-bill-to-keep-french-nuclear-reactor-offline |title=EDF faces £1m a day bill to keep French nuclear reactor offline |first=Adam |last=Vaughan |newspaper=The Guardian |date=21 February 2017 |accessdate=22 February 2017}} {{wide image|Kernkraftwerk Flamanville bei Nacht.jpg|800px|alt=Flamanville Nuclear Power Plant at night|Flamanville Nuclear Power Plant at night}} ==References== {{Commons category|Flamanville nuclear power plant}} {{Reflist|30em}} {{stack|{{Portal|France|Energy|Nuclear technology}}}} {{French nuclear power plants}} [[Category:Nuclear power stations in France]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations with reactors under construction]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations using EPR reactors]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Manche]]

In [[plasma physics]], the '''Hasegawa–Mima equation''', named after Akira Hasegawa and Kunioki Mima, is an equation that describes a certain regime of [[plasma (physics)|plasma]], where the time scales are very fast, and the distance scale in the direction of the [[magnetic field]] is long. In particular the equation is useful for describing [[turbulence]] in some [[tokamak]]s. The equation was introduced in Hasegawa and Mima's paper submitted in 1977 to ''Physics of Fluids'', where they compared it to the results of the ATC tokamak.
==Assumptions== * The magnetic field is large enough that:
::<math> \frac{1}{\omega_{ci}}\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \ll 1 </math>
:for all quantities of interest. When the particles in the plasma are moving through a magnetic field, they spin in a circle around the magnetic field. The frequency of oscillation, <math>\omega_{ci}</math> known as the [[cyclotron frequency]] or gyrofrequency, is directly proportional to the magnetic field.
* The particle density follows the [[quasineutrality condition]]:
::<math> n_e \approx Z n_i \, </math>
:where Z is the number of protons in the ions. If we are talking about hydrogen Z = 1, and n is the same for both species. This condition is true as long as the electrons can shield out electric fields. A cloud of electrons will surround any charge with an approximate radius known as the [[Debye length]]. For that reason this approximation means the size scale is much larger than the Debye length. The ion particle density can be expressed by a first order term that is the density defined by the quasineutrality condition equation, and a second order term which is how much it differs from the equation.
* The first order ion particle density is a function of position, but not time. This means that perturbations of the particle density change at a timescale much slower than the scale of interest. The second order particle density which causes a charge density and thus an electric potential can change with time. * The magnetic field, '''B''' must be uniform in space, and not be a function of time. The magnetic field also moves at a timescale much slower than the scale of interest. This allows the time derivative in the momentum balance equation to be neglected. * The ion temperature must be much smaller than the electron temperature. This means that the ion pressure can be neglected in the ion momentum balance equation. * The electrons follow a [[Boltzmann distribution]] where:
::<math> n = n_0 e^{e\phi/T_e} \, </math>
:Since the electrons are free to move along the direction of the magnetic field, they screen away electric potentials. This screening causes a Boltzmann distribution of electrons to form around the electric potentials.
==The equation== The Hasegawa–Mima equation is a second order nonlinear partial differential equation that describes the electric potential. The form of the equation is:
:<math> \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\nabla^2\phi-\phi\right)-\left[\left(\nabla\phi\times \mathbf{\hat z}\right)\cdot\nabla\right]\left[\nabla^2\phi-\ln\left(\frac{n_0}{\omega_{ci}}\right)\right]=0. </math>
Although the quasi neutrality condition holds, the small differences in density between the electrons and the ions cause an electric potential. The Hasegawa–Mima equation is derived from the continuity equation:
:<math> \frac{\partial n}{\partial t} + \nabla\cdot (n\mathbf{ v}) = 0. </math>
The fluid velocity can be approximated by the E cross B drift:
:<math> \mathbf{ v_E} = \frac{\mathbf{ E}\times \mathbf{ B}}{cB^2} = \frac{-\nabla\phi\times\mathbf{\hat z}}{cB}. </math>
Previous models derived their equations from this approximation. The divergence of the [[E cross B drift]] is zero, which keeps the fluid incompressible. However, the compressibility of the fluid is very important in describing the evolution of the system. Hasegawa and Mima argued that the assumption was invalid. The Hasegawa–Mima equation introduces a second order term for the fluid velocity known as the [[polarization drift]] in order to find the divergence of the fluid velocity. Due to the assumption of large magnetic field, the polarization drift is much smaller than the E cross B drift. Nevertheless, it introduces important physics.
For a two-dimensional incompressible fluid which is not a plasma, the [[Navier–Stokes equations]] say:
:<math> \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\nabla^2\psi\right)-\left[\left(\nabla\psi\times \mathbf{\hat z}\right)\cdot\nabla\right]\nabla^2\psi =0 </math>
after taking the curl of the momentum balance equation. This equation is almost identical to the Hasegawa–Mima equation except the second and fourth terms are gone, and the electric potential is replaced with the fluid velocity vector potential where:
:<math> \mathbf{ v} = -\nabla\psi\times\mathbf{\hat z}. </math>
The first and third terms to the Hasegawa–Mima equation, which are the same as the Navier Stokes equation, are the terms introduced by adding the polarization drift. In the limit where the wavelength of a perturbation of the electric potential is much smaller than the gyroradius based on the sound speed, the Hasegawa–Mima equations become the same as the two-dimensional incompressible fluid.
==Normalization== One way to understand an equation more fully is to understand what it is normalized to, which gives you an idea of the scales of interest. The time, position, and electric potential are normalized to t',x', and <math>\phi'</math>
The time scale for the Hasegawa–Mima equation is the inverse ion gyrofrequency:
:<math> t' = \omega_{ci} t, \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \omega_{ci} = \frac{eZB}{m_i c}. </math>
From the large magnetic field assumption the normalized time is very small. However, it is still large enough to get information out of it.
The distance scale is the [[gyroradius]] based on the sound speed:
:<math> x' = \frac{x}{\rho_s}, \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \rho_s^2 \equiv \frac{T_e}{m_i\omega_{ci}^2}. </math>
If you transform to k-space, it is clear that when k, the wavenumber, is much larger than one, the terms that make the Hasegawa–Mima equation differ from the equation derived from Navier-Stokes equation in a two dimensional incompressible flow become much smaller than the rest.
From the distance and time scales we can determine the scale for velocities. This turns out to be the sound speed. The Hasegawa–Mima equation, shows us the dynamics of fast moving sounds as opposed to the slower dynamics such as flows that are captured in the [[Magnetohydrodynamics|MHD equations]]. The motion is even faster than the sound speed given that the time scales are much smaller than the time normalization.
The potential is normalized to:
:<math> \phi' =\frac{e\phi}{T_e}. </math>
Since the electrons fit a [[Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution|Maxwellian]] and the quasineutrality condition holds, this normalized potential is small, but similar order to the normalized time derivative.
The entire equation without normalization is:
:<math> \frac{1}{\omega_{ci}}\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\rho_s^2\nabla^2\frac{e\phi}{T_e}-\frac{e\phi}{T_e}\right)-\left[\left(\rho_s\nabla \frac{e\phi}{T_e}\times \mathbf{\hat z}\right)\cdot\rho_s\nabla\right]\left[\rho_s^2\nabla^2\frac{e\phi}{T_e}-\ln\left(\frac{n_0}{\omega_{ci}}\right)\right]=0. </math>
Although the time derivative divided by the cyclotron frequency is much smaller than unity, and the normalized electric potential is much smaller than unity, as long as the gradient is on the order of one, both terms are comparable to the nonlinear term. The unperturbed density gradient can also be just as small as the normalized electric potential and be comparable to the other terms.
==Other forms of the equation== Often the Hasegawa–Mima equation is expressed in a different form using [[Poisson bracket]]s. These Poisson brackets are defined as:
:<math> \left[A,B\right] \equiv \frac{\partial A}{\partial x}\frac{\partial B}{\partial y}-\frac{\partial A}{\partial y}\frac{\partial B}{\partial x}. </math>
Using these Poisson brackets, the equation can be reexpressed as:
:<math> \frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\nabla^2\phi-\phi\right)+\left[\phi,\nabla^2\phi\right]-\left[\phi,\ln\left(\frac{n_0}{\omega_{ci}}\right)\right]=0. </math>
Often the particle density is assumed to vary uniformly just in one direction, and the equation is written in a sightly different form. The Poisson bracket including the density is replaced with the definition of the Poisson bracket, and a constant replaces the derivative of the density dependent term.
==Conserved quantities== There are two quantities that are conserved in a two-dimensional incompressible fluid. The [[kinetic energy]]:
:<math> \int\left(\nabla\psi\right)^2dV = \int v_x^2 + v_y^2\,dV. </math>
And the [[enstrophy]]:
:<math> \int\left(\nabla^2\psi\right)^2\,dV = \int\left(\nabla\times \mathbf{ v}\right)^2\,dV. </math>
For the Hasegawa–Mima equation, there are also two conserved quantities, that are related to the above quantities. The generalized energy:
:<math> \int\left[\phi^2+\left(\nabla\phi\right)^2\right]\,dV. </math>
And the generalized enstrophy:
:<math> \int\left[\left(\nabla\phi\right)^2+\left(\nabla^2\phi\right)^2\right]\,dV. </math>
In the limit where the Hasegawa–Mima equation is the same as an incompressible fluid, the generalized energy, and enstrophy become the same as the kinetic energy and enstrophy.
==See also== * [[Magnetohydrodynamics]] * [[Navier–Stokes equations]] * [[Plasma (physics)]] * [[Turbulence]]
==References== * Hasegawa, A., and Mima, K., Pseudo-three-dimensional turbulence in magnetized nonuniform plasma, ''Phys. Fluids'' '''21''', 87–92 (1978). * Hasegawa, A., and Mima, K., Stationary spectrum of strong turbulence in magnetized nonuniform plasma, ''Phys. Rev. Lett.'' '''39''', 205 (1977).
==External links== * http://www.ipp.mpg.de/~fsj/PAPERS_1/tutorial_3.pdf

'''Hopton Wood stone''' (sometimes '''Hopton-Wood stone''' or '''Hoptonwood stone''') is a type of [[limestone]] quarried west of [[Middleton-by-Wirksworth]], [[Derbyshire]], England.<ref name="BGS">{{cite web|url=http://www.bgs.ac.uk/foundation-web/HoptonWood.html|title=Bright Stone: Hopton Wood|accessdate=2 May 2013|publisher=[[British Geological Survey]]}}</ref> Described as "very fine, almost like marble"<ref name="Wirksworth">{{cite web|url=http://www.wirksworth.org.uk/A19-HOPT.htm|title=WIRKSWORTH-Parish Records 1608-1899-Hopton Stone|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref> and as "England’s premier decorative stone",<ref name="Thomas">{{cite journal|last=Thomas|first=Ian A|title=Hopton Wood Stone – England’s premier decorative stone|journal=England’s Heritage in Stone Proceedings of a Conference Tempest Anderson Hall, York 15–17 March 2005|pages=90–105|url=http://www.englishstone.org.uk/York/ESF%20-%20Ian%20Thomas.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514044950/http://www.englishstone.org.uk/York/ESF%20-%20Ian%20Thomas.pdf|archivedate=14 May 2014|df=}}</ref> it is particularly suited to carving, making it popular for [[tombstone]]s (including many thousands for the [[Commonwealth War Graves Commission]]<ref name="Wirksworth" /><ref name="Thomas" />), sculpture and building.
Buildings and structures made using Hopton Wood stone include the [[Houses of Parliament]],<ref name="Lowes">{{cite web|url=http://www.lowesmarble.com/Hopton-Wood-Limestone(1782994).htm |title=Hopton Wood Limestone |publisher=Lowes Marble and Granite |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130915010440/http://lowesmarble.com/Hopton-Wood-Limestone%281782994%29.htm |archivedate=15 September 2013 |df= }}</ref> [[Westminster Abbey]], the [[Albert Memorial]],<ref name="Lowes" /> [[Lichfield Cathedral]],<ref name="Lowes" /> [[Calke Abbey]],<ref name="Lowes" /> [[Chatsworth House]]<ref name="BGS" /> and [[Oscar Wilde's tomb]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Pennington|first=Michael|title=An Angel for a Martyr|year=1987|publisher=Whitenights Press|isbn=978-0704901131|page=32}}</ref>
In 1947 the Hopton-Wood Stone Firms Ltd commissioned a book about Hopton Wood stone, published by Fanfare press.<ref name="HWS-Book">{{cite web|url=http://www.hoptonwoodstone.co.uk/The%20Book.htm|title=The Book|accessdate=2 May 2013}}</ref>
